DOC.HEAD: Planes Bring Wounded From Panama to Texas Base
Eds: UPDATES throughout with more than 190 reported in San Antonio, conflicting figures from Pentagon. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Doctors and nurses at San Antonio military hospitals postponed holiday leaves and worked extra shifts today treating more than 190 soldiers hurt in Panama, the biggest influx of casualties here since Vietnam, officials said. Two C-141 transport planes carrying 85 soldiers arrived today at Kelly Air Force Base; two planes on brought 108 to Kelly on Wednesday, hospital spokesmen said. Four of the soldiers died en route here or after arrival. The Pentagon today reported 19 dead, one missing and 117 wounded; there was no immediate explanation of the discrepancy in the number hurt. Kelly officials were told their base would receive all the soldiers injured in the fighting in Panama. The wounded were taken by ambulance, bus and helicopter from Kelly to 1,000-bed Wilford Hall Medical Center at adjacent Lackland Air Force Base and to Brooke Army Medical Center, the military's leading burn unit. ``The biggest and the most extensive injuries are gunshot-type wounds, schrapnel-type wounds, leg wounds, broken bones, this sort of thing,'' said Lackland spokesman Lt. Col. Johnny Whitaker. Whitaker said it is the largest surge of injured at the San Antonio hospitals since the Vietnam War. He said the military would not release the names of the dead or injured until family members were notified. However, Whitaker said patients range in condition from fair to critical. Doctors and nurses were called in on extra shifts and some holiday leaves were delayed, he said. More than 200 military doctors and 500 nurses are stationed at Wilford Hall. The hospital, the Air Force's largest, also treated victims of the U.S. invasion of Grenada and the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Lebanon in 1983. Motels near Wilford Hall were offering complimentary rooms for relatives of wounded soldiers, Whitaker said. Reporters were kept outside a Lackland gate about a half-mile from the hospital, but ambulances could be seen shuttling between Wilford Hall and the Kelly tarmac.
